She says that she feels “empty inside” and has been hearing voices telling her that she is worthless. She first heard these voices 7 months ago when they started to make fun of her. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Physical and neurological exa...
judge_rationale: The patient meets criteria for schizoaffective disorder with both a major depressive episode (sadness, anhedonia, poor sleep/appetite, worthlessness) lasting 4 months and psychotic symptoms (auditory hallucinations) that preceded and persisted beyond the mood disturbance for 7 months, consistent with DSM-5 diagnostic requirements.

case_presentation: A 37-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after falling down a flight of stairs. On arrival, she has shortness of breath, right-sided chest pain, right upper quadrant abdominal pain, and right shoulder pain. She is otherwise healthy. She takes no medications. She appears pale. judge_rationale: The patient's hypotension, right upper quadrant pain, right shoulder pain (Kehr's sign), and evidence of trauma point to a liver hematoma with intraperitoneal hemorrhage, not a hemothorax, which typically presents with respiratory distress and flat neck veins are less specific.

case_presentation: A previously healthy 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of dizziness and palpitations for 2 days. Prior to the onset of the symptoms, he attended a bachelor party where he lost several drinking games. An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
judge_rationale: Atrial fibrillation is clinically correct as it identifies the arrhythmia, though 'paroxysmal' specifies the transient nature consistent with the acute presentation following alcohol consumption.

case_presentation: A 21-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with right arm pain and limited range of motion. She does not recall trauma to the arm. judge_rationale: The patient's recurrent, unexplained multisystem symptoms and frequent ER visits are classic for somatization disorder, while PID does not explain the arm symptoms or the chronic, recurrent pattern.

case_presentation: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of recurrent episodes of chest pain, difficulty breathing, and rapid heart beating over the past two months. During this period, he has had a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss, malaise, pain in both knees, and diffuse muscle pain. judge_rationale: The presentation with systemic symptoms, mononeuritis multiplex (implied by diffuse muscle pain), cutaneous ulcers, renal involvement, and hepatitis B infection is classic for polyarteritis nodosa, a medium-vessel vasculitis strongly associated with HBV.

He has chronic constipation for which he takes lactulose and senna laxatives. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F), blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg and pulse is 85/min. On physical examination, there is diffuse abdominal distension and tenderness, and bowel sounds are faint. His plain abdominal radiograph is shown. Which of the following is the most likel...
judge_rationale: The clinical presentation with colicky pain, distension, and constipation in an elderly patient with chronic laxative use, along with the mention of a plain radiograph (likely showing a 'coffee bean' sign or similar), is classic for sigmoid volvulus, not simple small bowel obstruction.

case_presentation: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician 3 months after noticing skin changes on his scalp. When he scrapes off the crust of the lesion, it reappears after a few days. Occasionally, his scalp itches or he notices a burning sensation. He had a mole removed on his right forearm 5 years ago. He is a retired winemaker. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple rough patches on his scalp. A photograph is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
judge_rationale: The patient's history of chronic sun exposure (winemaker), age, and description of rough patches on sun-exposed scalp that recur after removal are classic for actinic keratosis, which matches the gold answer.

case_presentation: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of intermittent episodes of shortness of breath, chest tightness, palpitation, dizziness, sweaty hands, and a feeling of impending doom. She says that her symptoms occur when she goes for a walk or waits in line for coffee. She reports that she no longer leaves the house by herself because she is afraid of being alone when her symptoms occur. She only goes out when her boyfriend accompanies her. She does not smoke or use illi...
judge_rationale: The patient's avoidance of leaving home alone due to fear of panic symptoms in situations where escape might be difficult is the hallmark of agoraphobia, not just panic disorder alone.

case_presentation: A 17-year-old high school student presents to your office for recent mood and skin changes. The patient is a high school senior who is competing on the wrestling team and recently has lost weight to drop two weight classes over the past several months. He states he has dry, cracking, and irritated skin, as well as a sensation of tingling in his hands and feet. The patient also states that he has not been feeling himself lately. He finds himself more irritable and no longer enjoys many of the act...
judge_rationale: Vitamin B6 deficiency is a specific type of water-soluble vitamin deficiency, and the presentation with dermatitis, peripheral neuropathy, mood changes, and elevated homocysteine is classic for B6 deficiency, especially in the context of potential supplement use or poor nutrition during weight cutting.

case_presentation: A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with her boyfriend 2 hours after an episode of loss of consciousness. She was seated and was being tattooed on her right upper flank when she became diaphoretic, pale, and passed out. According to her boyfriend, the patient slipped to the floor and her arms and legs moved in a jerky fashion for a few seconds. She regained consciousness within half a minute and was alert and fully oriented immediately. She has no history of serious illness. Sh...
judge_rationale: The presentation is classic for vasovagal syncope: triggered by a stressful stimulus (tattooing), prodrome of diaphoresis and pallor, brief loss of consciousness with possible myoclonic movements, rapid recovery, and normal examination aside from a common incidental ECG finding.

case_presentation: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of pain in her right thumb and wrist that radiates to her elbow. It is worse when she holds her infant son and improves with the use of an ice pack. Six months ago, she slipped on a wet floor and fell on her right outstretched hand. judge_rationale: Both answers refer to the same condition: De Quervain's tenosynovitis, characterized by radial wrist pain, tenderness over the radial styloid, and a positive Finkelstein test as described in the case.

case_presentation: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. The patient was the front seat unrestrained driver in a head on collision. case_presentation: A 34-year-old Ethiopian woman who recently moved to the United States presents for evaluation to a surgical outpatient clinic with painful ulceration in her right breast for the last 2 months. She is worried because the ulcer is increasing in size. On further questioning, she says that she also has a discharge from her right nipple. She had her 2nd child 4 months ago and was breastfeeding the baby until the pain started getting worse in the past few weeks, and is now unbearable. According to her...
judge_rationale: The presentation with painful breast ulceration, peau d'orange appearance, dermal lymphatic invasion on biopsy, and poor response to antibiotics is classic for inflammatory breast cancer, which matches both answers.
